thread.title: Blue Jays fans rally for Game 4 of ALCS against Royals
thread.title_full: Blue Jays fans rally for Game 4 of ALCS against Royals | Toronto Star

author: Robin Levinson King
title: Blue Jays fans rally for Game 4 of ALCS against Royals
text:
What year is it?
The Toronto Blue Jays are in the playoffs and the Liberal Party is in power — not all that different from 1993, when the Jays won the World Series just days before Jean Chretien’s sweeping victory.
“Pretty cool that yesterday was both the highest voter turnout and deepest post-season Jays game since 1993,” said one fan on social media.
But while Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau positively smashed it out of the park, securing a majority government, the Jays’ success has been more subdued.
The team has struggled against the Kansas City Royals, who are leading the American League Championship Series 2-1. The Jays’ Election Day 11-8 win over the Royals was bittersweet — after enjoying a 10-4 lead in the fifth inning, the Royals scored four runs in the ninth, closing the gap and nearly coming back.
After Monday night’s victory, Jays fans hope the team can get some momentum in Game 4.
“I'm not worried about the #Jays when the bats are back at home,” said Gregg Zaun, a Rogers Sportsnet baseball commentator and former Blue Jays catcher.
Jays manager John Gibbons is starting R.A. Dickey and Chris Young, but says he could use closer Robert Osuna or fellow reliever Aaron Sanchez.
Osuna has a slight problem with a cracked nail and Sanchez has a blister on his finger. Gibbons said the two are okay to pitch, but he would rest them if he could.
“We're concerned about it,” he said. “You don't want to get careless. But I mean they're not labouring enough or it's that painful. Guys get those throughout a year. You might give them a couple of days. Right now you really can't do that.”
The Blue Jays should get a boost of home game spirit from the Toronto Symphony Orchestra , which is scheduled to play the national anthem before Tuesday’s 4:07 p.m. game at Rogers Centre.
With files from The Canadian Press
